Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Kenneth C. Jeffries is "Questions in Invariant Theory and Multiplicities." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Michigan, and the sponsoring scientist is Harm Derksen.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship Questions in Invariant Theory and Multiplicities was focused on the study of solutions of systems of equations in many vairables. A key question that was considered was that of how many polynomial equations are needed to tell apart points up to symmetry, and progress was made in joint work with Dufresne. Another theme of the research was to study small-scale properties of solution sets of equations. For example, one can have smooth points, which look flat from a very close view, or singular points, which look like crossings or corners, no matter how closely one looks. This project considered singular points in high-dimensional spaces, and studied them by considering ways to assign numbers to points to measure how singular they are: how bad of a corner or crossing in many dimensions. We yielded many results on this theme in joint work with Brenner, N??ez, Hern?ndez, Smirnov, and others. Another important research theme was that of connections to neuroscience.This is motivated by the question in mathematical biology of how the brain organizes data. Many phenomena are organized in such a way that particular neurons will fire when a stimulus is in a particular convex set within the stimulus space. To determine which phenomena are organized in this way, we applied novel algebraic techniques.

This project also supported a number of contributions to education and development of human resources. Supported by the grant, the investigator led two different undergraduate summer research projects with G?nt?rk?n, Canton, and Grifo. One lead to a publication with an undergraduate. The PI participated as an instructor in workshops for graduate students, and developed substantial course materials and made them publicly available on his website.

Finally, this grant made a substantial impact on the career of the recipient. Awarded at an intermediate career stage, the recipient was able to form new collaborations and undertake more ambitious research. The recipient now works at a tenure-track position at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.
